raw_text:
China continues breakneck growth
 
 China's economy has expanded by a breakneck 9.5% during 2004, faster than predicted and well above 2003's 9.1%.
 
 The news may mean more limits on investment and lending as Beijing tries to take the economy off the boil. China has sucked in raw materials and energy to feed its expansion, which could have knock-on effects on the rest of the world if it overheats. But officials pointed out that industrial growth had slowed, with services providing much of the impetus. Growth in industrial output - the main target of government efforts to impose curbs on credit and investments - was 11.5% in 2004, down from 17% the previous year.
 
 Still, consumer prices - at 2.4% - rose faster than in 2004, adding to concern that a sharp rise in producer prices of 7.1% could stoke inflation. And overall investment in fixed assets was still high, up 21.3% from the previous year - although some way off the peak of 43% seen in the first quarter of 2004. The result could be higher interest rates. China raised rates by 0.27 percentage points to 5.8% - its first hike in nine years - in October 2004.
 
 Despite the apparent rebalancing of the economy the overall growth picture remains strong, economists said. "There is no sign of a slowdown in 2005," said Tim Congdon, economist at ING Barings.
 
 China's economy is not only gathering speed thanks to domestic demand, but also from soaring sales overseas. Figures released earlier this year showed exports at a six-year high in 2004, up 35%. Part of the impetus comes from the relative cheapness of the yuan, China's currency. The government keeps it pegged close to a rate of 8.28 to the US dollar, - much to the chagrin of many US lawmakers who blame China for lost jobs and competitiveness. Despite urging to ease the peg, officials insist they are a long way from ready to make a shift to a more market-set rate. "We need a good and feasible plan and formulating such a plan also needs time," National Bureau of Statistics chief Li Deshui told Reuters. "Those who hope to make a fortune by speculating on a renminbi revaluation will not succeed in making a profit."
llama3.2:1b: China's economy grew 9.5% in 2004, faster than predicted and above 2003's growth, but slowed industrial growth to 11.5%.
Industrial output rose 17% the previous year.
Consumer prices rose to 2.4%, adding concern that producer prices could lead to higher inflation.
China raised interest rates by 0.27 percentage points in October 2004 to 5.8%.
Despite a strong overall growth picture, economists say there is no sign of slowing down in 2005.
llama3.2:3b: China's economy expanded 9.5% in 2004, faster than predicted, with services driving growth and industrial output slowing to 11.5%.
Consumer prices rose 2.4%, inflation concerns remain, and interest rates were raised for the first time in nine years to 5.8%.
Exports reached a six-year high of 35% due to cheap yuan, but officials resist pegging it to market rate.
gemma2:2b: China's economy grew 9.5% in 2004, exceeding expectations and fueled by both domestic demand and strong exports.
However, rising producer prices and investment activity may lead to higher interest rates and inflation concerns.
While the overall growth picture remains strong, economists expect continued momentum in 2005.
Despite pressure for a shift away from the fixed currency peg system, China maintains its current policy.
qwen2.5:0.5b: China's economy is growing quickly, expanding by 9.5% in the second half of 2004 compared to 9.1% in the first half.
Some experts believe this growth could put upward pressure on interest rates and inflation if industrial output slows down further.
Overall economic growth remains strong as consumer prices rise faster than expected and fixed asset investment continues to grow.
qwen2.5:1.5b: China's economy grew at an accelerated pace, expanding 9.5% in 2004 from 2003's 9.1%, driven largely by services and slowing industrial output growth.
Consumer prices increased faster than in previous years, raising concerns about inflation, while overall investment remained high despite earlier signs of rebalancing.
China maintained interest rate hikes following an 0.27 percentage point increase to 5.8%.
Despite these developments, economists remain confident the economy will continue to grow strongly.
qwen2.5:3b: China's economy expanded by 9.5% in 2004, significantly faster than predicted and surpassing the previous year's growth of 9.1%.
While industrial output grew at 11.5%, down from 17% in 2003, consumer prices rose to 2.4%, prompting concerns about potential inflation.
Despite some slowdowns, investment in fixed assets remained high at 21.3%, though this is less than the peak of 43% seen earlier in 2004.
In response, China raised interest rates to 5.8%.
Economists expect continued strong growth despite recent economic rebalancing efforts.
Additionally, soaring overseas sales and the relative cheapness of the yuan (at a pegged rate close to 8.28 to the US dollar) have contributed significantly to this growth.
Despite pressure from some observers, China remains committed to maintaining its current currency pegging strategy.
opencoder:1.5b: China's economy has expanded by a breakneck 9.5% during 2004, faster than predicted and well above 2003's 9.1%.
The news may mean more limits on investment and lending as Beijing tries to take the economy off the boil.
China has sucked in raw materials and energy to feed its expansion, which could have knock-on effects on the rest of the world if it overheats.
Still, consumer prices - at 2.4% - rose faster than in 2004, adding to concern that a sharp rise in producer prices of 7.1% could stoke inflation.
And overall investment in fixed assets was still high, up 21.3% from the previous year - although some way off the peak of 43% seen in the first quarter of 2004.
China raised rates by 0.27 percentage points to 5.8% - its first hike in nine years - in October 2004.
China's economy is not only gathering speed thanks to domestic demand, but also from soaring sales overseas.
Figures released earlier this year showed exports at a six-year high in 2004, up 35%.
Economists say there is no sign of a slowdown in 2005, Tim Congdon, economist at ING Barings.
smollm:1.7b: China's economy has continued to breakneck growth, driven by strong domestic demand and rising exports.

The news may mean more limits on investment and lending as Beijing tries to impose curbs on the economy, but it also highlights China's ability to manage its economic growth without relying heavily on foreign capital.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: China's economy expanded 9.5% in 2004, outperforming expectations.
Investment and lending might be restricted to balance the economy.
Use of raw materials and energy led to slowdown in industrial growth, driven by services.
Consumer prices rose faster than before, worried about inflation.
Fixed asset investment was up 21.3%, near potential peak but far from its previous peak of 43%.
Interest rates were expected to rise slightly, reaching 5.8% for China's first hike in nine years.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Chinese economy continued to grow at breakneck pace, growing by a 9.5% rate during 2004, even as the government tries to reduce industrial growth and investment.
Despite consumer prices rising more than expected, overall investment in fixed assets was still high, indicating strong demand for property and infrastructure projects.
This suggests that China will not slow down its economy anytime soon.
The country's economic growth has also attracted foreign investors with low operating costs and the country's cheap currency.
Despite calls from US lawmakers to ease up on China's yuan policy, officials insist they are taking a cautious approach towards such measures.
tinydolphin:1.1b: China continues to expand its economy at a faster pace than predicted, with GDP growth at 9.5% during 2004.
This rapid growth is fueled by an expansion of domestic demand and increased investment, according to Chinese officials.

However, concerns over China's ability to slow down its economic growth and achieve its growth targets have emerged as the government struggles to implement its plans for controlling credit and investments.
The breakneck pace of China's economy has been driven by increased industrial output, which saw a 11.5% increase in 2004 compared to 2003.
Growth in industrial production was mainly driven by services as the country continues to focus on increasing employment and reducing inflation.
Despite concerns over the potential impact of an overheating economy on consumer prices, official data shows that consumer prices have increased at a more moderate rate than in 2004.
The National Bureau of Statistics has projected an increase in consumer prices for 2005 at 2.4% from 2004's 2.6%.

Despite these economic indicators, concerns over China's interest rates have persisted as the central bank raises its rate by 0.27 percentage points to maintain a stable exchange rate and reduce borrowing costs for businesses.
In October 2004, China raised rates by 0.27 percentage points to 5.8%, marking its first increase in nine years.
This move has been criticized for not having a clear economic justification and the potential impact on domestic producers of fixed assets, such as infrastructure investment.
Despite the impressive growth statistics, critics have noted that China's overall growth picture remains strong, with many economists predicting higher interest rates in 2005.
In a statement, ING Barings economist Tim Congdon said, "There is no sign of a slowdown in 2005."

Despite concerns over a potential rebalancing of the economy, China's economy remains strong and has managed to gather significant sales overseas, which indicates an increased competitiveness among domestic producers.
phi:2.7b: China's economy grew at an unprecedented rate of 9.5% in 2004, exceeding previous predictions and raising concerns about inflation due to rising producer prices.
Industrial output growth slowed down from 17% to 11.5%, but consumer prices rose faster than the target of 2.4%.
Despite these factors, overall investment levels remained high, leading to potential interest rate hikes.
However, China's strong economy is not solely driven by domestic demand, but also by soaring overseas sales.
The government has kept the yuan pegged at a relatively low exchange rate of 8.28 to the US dollar, despite pressure from some American lawmakers.
National Bureau of Statistics chief Li Deshui expressed the need for careful planning before changing the currency's value.
orca-mini:3b: China's economy expanded by 9.5% during 2004, faster than predicted and above 2003's 9.1%.
Industrial growth slowed to 11.5% in 2004 from 17% the previous year, while consumer prices rose by 2.4% and overall investment in fixed assets was still high at 21.3%.
However, higher interest rates were raised by 0.27 percentage points to 5.8%, suggesting a rebalancing of the economy towards domestic demand and away from exports.
Despite the apparent slowdown, China's economy remains strong and exports continued to rise in 2004, up 35%.
However, officials warned against speculation on a renminbi revaluation and those hoping to make a fortune by speculating on a currency appreciation will not succeed.
hermes3:3b: China's economy grew 9.5% in 2004, faster than predicted.
China aims to slow down growth but concerns about inflation, investment levels and potential overheating persist.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: In 2004, China's economy experienced rapid growth of 9.5%, exceeding expectations and surpassing the previous year's rate of 9.1%.
This growth was driven primarily by services rather than industrial output, which saw an 11.5% increase compared to the previous year.
Nevertheless, consumer prices rose faster at 2.4%, increasing concerns about potential inflation.
Although overall investment in fixed assets remained high, at 21.3%, experts predicted strong overall growth for 2005 despite attempts by Beijing to impose limits on credit and investments.
China raised interest rates for the first time in nine years in October 2004.
Part of this growth came from increased exports, reaching a six-year high of 35% in 2004 due to the relative affordability of the yuan, China's currency pegged close to 8.28 US dollars.
However, the government is reluctant to adjust the peg and sees no immediate plans for revaluing the renminbi.
chatgpt-4o-latest: China's economy grew by 9.5% in 2004, surpassing expectations and 2003's 9.1% growth.
The rapid expansion has led to concerns about overheating, prompting Beijing to impose limits on investment and lending.
Industrial growth slowed to 11.5% from 17% in 2003, while services drove much of the growth.
Consumer prices rose by 2.4%, and producer prices increased by 7.1%, raising inflation concerns.
Fixed asset investment remained high at 21.3% growth, though lower than early 2004 peaks.
Interest rates were raised for the first time in nine years to 5.8%.
Despite efforts to rebalance, strong growth is expected to continue in 2005, driven by domestic demand and a 35% surge in exports.
The yuan remains pegged at 8.28 to the US dollar, despite US pressure for revaluation, with Chinese officials insisting they are not ready for a market-driven exchange rate.
stablelm2:1.6b: China's economy experienced breakneck growth of 9.5% during 2014, surpassing expectations and exceeding the predicted 9.1%.
However, investment and lending may face restrictions due to the overheating global energy market.
Despite slower industrial growth compared to previous years, services are still driving the impetus for expansion.

In contrast..
  
China's industrial output grew by 5.0% in Q4 2014 after a 9.0% increase in Q3 2014, while industrial growth slowed down to 5.5% from an 8.2% in Q4 2.
Concerns about high inflation persist due to rising consumer prices at 2.4%.
The overall investment in fixed assets was still relatively high at 3.3% YoY (year-on-year) growth.
China raised interest rates by 0.6 percentage points, reaching a rate of 5.8%, which is its first hike in nine years.
China's overall growth remains strong due to both domestic demand and increasing sales abroad.
Exports have reached the highest level in six years, up 3.0% YoY (year-on-year), with part of this surge attributed to the relatively cheap yuan.
However, China continues to maintain its currency peg close to a rate of 8.0 against the US dollar despite opposition from some US lawmakers who blame China for lost jobs and competitiveness.
Officials have stated they are a long way from ready to make any significant shift in their fixed-currency strategy.
"We need a good and feasible plan; we don L need to formulate such a plan just yet," National Bureau of Statistics chief Li Deshui told Reuters.
granite3.1-dense:2b: China's economy experienced a rapid 9.5% growth in 2004, surpassing the previous year's rate of 9.1%.
This expansion was driven primarily by increased domestic demand and exports, with industrial output growth slowing to 11.5%, down from 17% the year prior.
Consumer prices rose faster than in 2004, adding to inflation concerns, while overall investment in fixed assets remained high at 21.3%.
To mitigate potential overheating, China raised interest rates by 0.27 percentage points to 5.8%, marking its first hike in nine years.
Despite these measures, economists see no signs of a slowdown in 2005.
The strong growth is attributed to both increased domestic consumption and robust export sales, which reached six-year highs with a 35% increase.
China's currency, the yuan, remains artificially low, pegged near 8.28 per US dollar.

Although some US lawmakers advocate for a renminbi revaluation to address job losses and competitiveness concerns, officials have not committed to this change, emphasizing the need for a well-planned transition.
